attributes.description:
Below are a summary of 3 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Childhood Maltreatment Was Correlated With the Decreased Cortical Function in Depressed Patients Under Social Stress in a Working Memory Task: A Pilot Study
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.671574
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: inverse
Supporting text used in extraction: We find a strong correlation between GPA/Grades/Measures of Academic Success and psychological distress and suicidality.

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: inverse
Supporting text used in extraction: Results of a previous study indicated that rejection sensitivity plays a role in the development of ADA in patients with SAD in the following three ways: (1) rejection sensitivity triggers ADA directly; (2) rejection sensitivity intensifies depressive symptoms, which leads to ADA; and (3) rejection sensitivity intensifies social anxiety symptoms, which worsens depressive symptoms, which in turn leads to ADA.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: inverse
Supporting text used in extraction: These are risk factors for more a severe course of illness, and despite the considerable relapse risk of MDD, few interventions target the remitted phase, a high-risk period for developing new episodes.

Below are a summary of 5 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Childhood Maltreatment Was Correlated With the Decreased Cortical Function in Depressed Patients Under Social Stress in a Working Memory Task: A Pilot Study
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.671574
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: direct
Supporting text used in extraction: We find a strong correlation between stress level and allostatic load and psychological distress and suicidality.

Paper number 1

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Cognitive deficits in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome compared to those with major depressive disorder and healthy controls
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1016/j.clineuro.2010.12.002
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: direct
Supporting text used in extraction: We find a strong correlation between stress level and allostatic load and psychological distress and suicidality.

Paper number 3
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: direct
Supporting text used in extraction: A large meta-analysis found small to large effects sizes for cognitive deficits in remitted MDD populations, measured objectively by neuropsychological tests, across most domains of cognitive functioning, excluding auditory attention, general cognitive ability, autobiographical memory, in addition to inhibition unconstrained by speed.

Paper number 4
Opinion from: Brain activation patterns in major depressive disorder and work stress-related long-term sick leave 
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3109/10253890.2011.646347
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: direct
Supporting text used in extraction: This study used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate potential differences in brain activation patterns in patients with stress-related long-term sick leave (LTSL) and major depression. The results suggest a relationship between stress level and allostatic load and psychological distress and suicidality.

Paper DOI <link>: 10.3109/10253890.2011.646347
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: direct
Supporting text used in extraction: The study found that patients on long-term sick leave due to work stress exhibited a marked decrease in the reactivity of the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis. This suggests a relationship between psychological distress and suicidality and stress level and allostatic load.
